author: kipit
content:
Hello everyone, 

quick question about the yellow paper, in the *6.2 Execution* (https://ethereum.github.io/yellowpaper/paper.pdf#subsection.6.2) 

Are the 2 repetitions underlined in blue typos?

thanks

author: pipermerriam
content: What do you expect them to be?  Why do you think they are typos?

author: kipit
content: I do not understand why the 'to' address for the transaction (T*t*) and the transaction value (T*v*) would be included twice in the tuple

author: pipermerriam
content: Sorry, first glance at tiny subscripts I wasn't seeing that those were the same.  I'd open an issue in the yellow paper repository.  Looks like a typo.

author: kipit
content:
Ok thanks for the confirmation ðŸ™‚

Is this the repository I need to open the issue on?
https://github.com/ethereum/yellowpaper

author: kipit
content:
issue opened !
it's a bit ridiculous since it's just a typo, but I'm still proud to open my first issue ðŸ¥³

author: yperbasis
content: Those are not typos: please see the definition of Theta in section 8 "Message Call", Equation (102).

author: kipit
content: Oooh thanks gonna check that right away !

author: kipit
content:
Those 2 are indeed different, not easy to understand that in the equation 63 though 

thanks for the help <@!583892532644151312>  and to bad for my open issue haha

author: yperbasis
content: Sure. IMHO the Yellow Paper is not optimized for readability unfortunately, but at the moment it's the only formal description of Eth1x.

author: pipermerriam
content: Not too bad.  That issue can now serve as documentation for someone who comes along in the future with the same confusion.

author: pipermerriam
content: (if you maybe include the explanation in it when you close the issue)

author: kipit
content: Good idea, I'm editing it right now

author: pipermerriam
content: MEV has been a pretty commonly expressed topic of interest for CDAP applicants.  I'm not sure if anyone is planning to try and focus on this, but if you are, I think one thing that may be quite valuable is aggregating all of the proposed solutions that you can find, categorizing and analyzing them, and breaking them down into an easy to consume resource.  My guess is that lots of people are going to re-invent the same wheels and potentially waste effort hammering at the same solutions that are either known to be flawed in some way.

author: austinhx
content: Hey, has the program officially begun?

author: peter.davies
content:
I honestly think there is a huge scope for information gathering and organization in general.
I'm thinking of proposing a "document verkle tries" project. The information about is dispersed over loads of random blogs and hackmds and it's quite hard to find everything.

author: potuz
content: One of the projects I still need to take notes is about this. The same applies for sharding and the separation of shard block proposer and builder which is even being implemented now. Another is data visualization, with the merge we will have a lot of data available to analyze and very little is out there in terms of coherently reporting aggregated data. There are a few projects that would be useful and do not require neither new research nor new implementation since already everything has been done or is on its way, but still would be very useful to document

author: pipermerriam
content: No uniform start date. Everyone may/will move at their own pace and may/will need different amounts of time for each stage. Some have started, some are just getting started, some will start soon
